The book is ""The Wandering Falcon"" by Jamil Ahmad.
Our reviewer, Alan Cheuse, teaches writing at George Mason University in Fairfax, Virginia.
The Summer Olympics have not come to America since the 1996 Games in Atlanta.
Now Chicago wants them back.
Today an International Olympic Committee evaluation team begins a visit to Chicago.
It'll be checking out the city's planned Olympic sites as it scrutinizes a bid to hold the Games in 2016.
NPR's Cheryl Corley reports.
Unidentified Children: Chicago.
Unidentified Children: 2016.
Unidentified Children: 2016.
Lori Healey is the president of the Chicago 2016 effort.

Obviously we have a great story to tell about our plan to host the Games - how beautiful our city is, the diversity of our people, which is a significant advantage for us in talking about Chicago, because we are reflective of the IOC.
Unidentified Man: When they see the expansive blue waters of the lake, it could easily be mistaken for an ocean.
(SOUNDBITE OF VIDEO)
A number of the planned game venues, including the Olympic Village, will be clustered near Chicago's lake.
In addition to touring venues, the evaluation commission will take part in 17 technical presentations.
The cost of the bid - nearly $5 billion, financed mostly by the private sector.
Chicago Mayor Richard Daley says the financing is sound and the city will benefit.

The 2016 Games would leave a lasting legacy in the form of affordable housing, athletic facilities, ensuring that the Olympic Games will have a strong physical presence in Chicago for generations to come.
Not everybody likes the idea of Chicago hosting the Olympics in 2016.
I'm Bob Quellos and I'm with No Games Chicago.
No Games Chicago plans to hold a protest rally later today in Chicago's Federal Plaza.
Quellos says the city and state have large budget deficits, as do the Chicago public schools.

And it seems like the priorities of this city should really be on actually figuring out how to make these things work and not dedicating its time and energy to basically a three-week party seven years from now.
Chicago police also plan to hold a protest rally over contract negotiations.
2016 organizers say they don't expect the demonstrations to disturb the bid, so they're asking Chicagoans to show community support while the IOC is in town.
And in a new video, Olympian and former Chicago basketball star Michael Jordon has this message for the commission.
(SOUNDBITE OF VIDEO)
The Olympic spirit is alive in Chicago.
We're ready.
Cheryl Corley, NPR News, Chicago.

As early as Monday of this week, news stations began running countdown clocks, ticking away to a government shutdown.
If those clocks had reached zero with no budget deal, parts of the government would have closed and around 800,000 federal employees would have been furloughed.
Both houses of Congress and the president negotiated to the last minute, leaving the country on the edge of its seat.
Thirteen hours left for lawmakers to reach a budget deal and prevent that government shutdown.

A poll, which was commissioned by and abortions rights group, but conducted by professional pollsters, shows that 62 percent of South Dakotans thought the abortion law, as written, is too extreme.
That poll is disputed by anti-abortion groups, which point to piles of widely accepted polling that show that in general the people of South Dakota are against abortion.
After the state's governor, Mike Rounds, signed the bill, a poll conducted by the independent Survey USA, showed his popularity ratings drop by 14 percentage points.
Abortion foes say that might have been his toughest week as governor, and he still has a 58 percent approval rating.
He'll be an asset in the upcoming fight.
South Dakotans have many months of ads, arguments, surveys and soundbites to look forward to.
Mike Pesca, NPR News.
Still with sport; this time, football.
Millions of fans will tune in tonight to watch the Philadelphia Eagles play their division rival the Dallas Cowboys.
What they won't see, though, is Philadelphia's star wide receiver Terrell Owens.

His off-field complaints about his coach, his quarterback, his team--these have brought him a suspension and deactivation that's going to keep him off the field for the rest of the season, even though he later apologized.
I know in my heart that I can help this team win the Super Bowl, and not only being a dominant player, but also being a team player.
I can bring that.
Writer Jimi Izrael says Terrell Owens has learned that lesson of being a team player too late.
Terrell Owens isn't the kind of bad-boy athlete we've come to know.
He's not been caught doing drugs or ditching thousands of dollars in the champagne room.
His crimes are a little more pedestrian, insofar as, well, he's obnoxious.
He's just like that rude but efficient mail room clerk that always has the wrong thing to say at the worst times.
His quarterback, Donovan McNabb, calls him one of the best receivers in the league, while Owens calls McNabb tired and out of shape.
Talk about magnanimous.
I think Owens calls himself trying to keep it real in the workplace, but the workplace is no place for that.
Maybe he's lashing out for other reasons.
He said his team showed a lack of class for not publicly recognizing his hundredth career touchdown.
No one wants to hear millionaire athletes whine about being undervalued, but you know what?
He's right.
Sometimes a six-figure paycheck just isn't enough.
Who among us doesn't appreciate a nice sheet cake or a balloon bouquet to signify a job well done?
But no matter what, getting along with workmates is always a plus, especially when your workmates are charged with protecting you from 350-pound men intent on ripping your head off.
Even when your workplace is the football field, you kind of just have to show up and do your job.
Owens could benefit from a little something I call `slipping under the radar.
It's served me well at the office.
Now I don't grandstand, lash out or badmouth my workmates around the water cooler; I do my work.
And then?
Then I go home or to the corner bar, where I can talk some serious smack.
Owens needs some bar friends to air his gripes forth so he can keep his mouth shut in front of the press.
I think rapper-turned-actor Ice-T said it best: `There is freedom of speech in America, but watch what you say.
And if what you say causes your paycheck to come up short, guess what?
Your free speech ain't so free anymore.
Nothing cool about being broke, boisterous and unemployed.
Just ask Dennis Rodman.
a better way to deal with his feelings.
I can certainly see him and his teammates on a very special episode of ""Dr.
Phil,"" or maybe Oprah Winfrey's kitchen-sink wisdom can prove a potent mediation tool.
Or maybe he'll just learn to keep his mouth shut.
Keeping it real is one thing, but there's a lot to be said for just keeping it right.
Jimi Izrael is a columnist for AOL Black Voices.
I'm Alex Chadwick.
NPR's DAY TO DAY continues.
